awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Organizational Capacity and Capacity Building for Cyberinfrastructure Diffusion
awd_abstract_narration:
The vision behind advanced cyberinfrastructure (CI) is that its development, acquisition, and provision will transform science and engineering in the 21st century. However, CI diffusion is full of challenges, because the adoption of the material objects also requires the adoption of a set of related behavioral practices and philosophical ideologies. Most critically, CI-enabled virtual organizations (VOs) often lack the full range of organizational capacity to effectively integrate and support the complex web of objects, practices, and ideologies as a holistic innovation.

This project examines the various manifestations of CI related objects, practices, and ideologies, and the ways they support CI implementation in scientific VOs. Using grounded theory analysis of interviews and factor analysis of survey data, this project will develop and validate a robust framework/measure of organizational capacity for CI diffusion. The project's empirical focus will be the NSF-funded Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE; https://www.xsede.org/), a nationwide network of distributed high-performance computing resources. Interviews and surveys will solicit input from domain scientists, computational technologists, and supercomputer center administrators (across e-science projects, institutions, and disciplines) who have experience with adopting and using CI tools within the XSEDE ecosystem. The project will generate a series of capacity building strategies to help VOs increase the organizational capacity necessary to fully adopt CI. Findings will help NSF and other federal agencies to improve existing and future CI investments. This project may also have implications for open-source and commercial technologies that harness big data for complex simulations, modeling, and visualization analysis.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigates the social and organizational aspects of cyberinfrastructure (CI), a constellation of technologies and experts that enable scientists to harness big data for breakthrough discoveries in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Findings include the realization that CI is a multi-dimensional innovation, and the capacity required for its meaningful adoption is multi-level. More specifically, the adoption of CI as an innovation requires the adoption of the technology, the behaviors surrounding the technology, and the philosophy behind the technology, and some or all three dimensions could depart drastically from ?business as usual? for many potential adopters, thus impeding its diffusion and spread in the US. 

Also, the adoption and implementation of CI require capacity at the individual-, team-, institutional-, and community-levels. Effective adoption would require optimal alignments across all four levels, but this is often not the case for many adopters in this early phase of CI development, given the long-term nature of this innovation. This is an explanation for why CI adoption has not been easy to theorize, especially for users coming from disciplines and/or domains that traditionally lack capacity at some and/or all four levels specified. The mindset that ?If you build it [cyberinfrastructure], they [users] will come? was identified in this project as a limited mindset. Additional efforts and resources are required to attend to the social and organizational challenges, and to help CI get adopted and implemented effectively by new and future users in order to further maximize the NSF?s investment in building this large-scale and complex socio-technical innovation to advance STEM with big data in the US.

Educationally, this project inspired two new courses ?Diffusion of Innovations? (graduate level) and ?Capacity Building in Organizations? (undergraduate level) designed and delivered at Chapman University (a Primarily Undergraduate Institution) and/or Texas Tech University (a Hispanic-Serving Institution). The project also offered hands-on research training experiences to a total of 23 students across six years of the project. This leads to an average of about 3.83 (or 4) students per year. The students can be generally described as follows: 18 (78%) females, 10 (43%) students of color, 17 (74%) from an undergraduate institution (Chapman), and 14 (61%) undergraduates. During the last two years of the project, the PI moved to Texas Tech University and involved four PhD students there for the remainder of the project. Furthermore, a master?s level research staff and a PhD-level post-doctoral scholar were involved at Chapman University.

The project conducted more than 180 in-depth interviews and collected more than 180 online survey responses from CI professionals and users across the US and from a range of institutions. The research data allowed the principal investigator (PI) and his student team to generate about 28 student research posters (primarily led by undergraduate students), two journal articles, five proceedings publications, four peer-reviewed conference papers, two conference panel presentations, and two book chapters, including one in the prestigious Second International Handbook of Internet Research (Springer). Although the project has officially concluded in 2021, the PI anticipates more publications and educational opportunities coming out of this project for many years to come.
